title: phylotypr
text: get started ’ll need install phylotypr using either commands: get access packages function demonstration version training data, ’ll need run library() function. classification algorithm makes use random number generator, strongly encourage set seed get consistent results:
code: # devtools::install_github("riffomonas/phylotypr") #install development version install.packages("phylotypr") # install stable version from CRAN library(phylotypr) library(purrr) set.seed(19760620) # pat's birtday in YYYYMMDD format

title: phylotypr
text: can classify sequence, need generate database. can done using build_kmer_database() function takes several seconds execute. Unless save database object (e.g. db ) Rda-formatted file, ’ll need run function time load phylotypr default, build_kmer_database() use 8-nt long kmers calculate probabilities. size can altered user needed, 8-nt performs well shouldn’t need adjusted.
code: db <- build_kmer_database(   trainset9_pds$sequence,   trainset9_pds$taxonomy )

title: phylotypr
text: classify sequence need DNA sequence character object like unknown . unknown object can classified using classify_sequence() along database object (.e., db). output classify_sequence list taxonomic levels kingdom (domain) genus confidence scores sequence taxonomic levels example, ’ll notice family genus assignment confidence scores 80%. value commonly used mothur used RDP website. filter classification level confidence, can use filter_taxonomy() function: see “Porphyromonadaceae” “Barnesiella” names removed along confidence score. convert list format string, can use print_taxonomy() function:
code: unknown <- "TACGGAGGATGCGAGCGTTATCCGGATTTATTGGGTTTAAAGGGTGCGTAGGCGGATCGTTAAGTCAGTGGTCAAATTGAGGGGCTCAACCCCTTCCCGCCATTGAAACTGGCGATCTTGAGTGGAAGAGAAGTATGCGGAATGCGTGGTGTAGCGGTGAAATGCATAGATATCACGCAGAACCCCGATTGCGAAGGCAGCATGCCGGCTTCCTACTGACGCTCATGCACGAAAGTGTGGGTAACGAACAGG" consensus <- classify_sequence(unknown = unknown, database = db) consensus #> $taxonomy #> [1] "Bacteria"               "\"Bacteroidetes\""      "\"Bacteroidia\""        #> [4] "\"Bacteroidales\""      "\"Porphyromonadaceae\"" "Barnesiella"            #>  #> $confidence #> [1] 1.00 0.95 0.83 0.83 0.79 0.56 filtered <- filter_taxonomy(consensus) filtered #> $taxonomy #> [1] "Bacteria"          "\"Bacteroidetes\"" "\"Bacteroidia\""   #> [4] "\"Bacteroidales\"" #>  #> $confidence #> [1] 1.00 0.95 0.83 0.83 print_taxonomy(filtered) #> [1] "Bacteria(100);\"Bacteroidetes\"(95);\"Bacteroidia\"(83);\"Bacteroidales\"(83);\"Bacteroidales\"_unclassified(83);\"Bacteroidales\"_unclassified(83)"

title: phylotypr
text: multiple sequences like classify, can use map_chr() function purrr, something like . show classify sequence three times.
code: unknowns <- c(   "TACGGAGGATGCGAGCGTTATCCGGATTTATTGGGTTTAAAGGGTGCGTAGGCGGATCGTTAAGTCAGTGGTCAAATTGAGGGGCTCAACCCCTTCCCGCCATTGAAACTGGCGATCTTGAGTGGAAGAGAAGTATGCGGAATGCGTGGTGTAGCGGTGAAATGCATAGATATCACGCAGAACCCCGATTGCGAAGGCAGCATGCCGGCTTCCTACTGACGCTCATGCACGAAAGTGTGGGTAACGAACAGG",   "TACGGAGGATGCGAGCGTTATCCGGATTTATTGGGTTTAAAGGGTGCGTAGGCGGATCGTTAAGTCAGTGGTCAAATTGAGGGGCTCAACCCCTTCCCGCCATTGAAACTGGCGATCTTGAGTGGAAGAGAAGTATGCGGAATGCGTGGTGTAGCGGTGAAATGCATAGATATCACGCAGAACCCCGATTGCGAAGGCAGCATGCCGGCTTCCTACTGACGCTCATGCACGAAAGTGTGGGTAACGAACAGG",   "TACGGAGGATGCGAGCGTTATCCGGATTTATTGGGTTTAAAGGGTGCGTAGGCGGATCGTTAAGTCAGTGGTCAAATTGAGGGGCTCAACCCCTTCCCGCCATTGAAACTGGCGATCTTGAGTGGAAGAGAAGTATGCGGAATGCGTGGTGTAGCGGTGAAATGCATAGATATCACGCAGAACCCCGATTGCGAAGGCAGCATGCCGGCTTCCTACTGACGCTCATGCACGAAAGTGTGGGTAACGAACAGG" )  purrr::map_chr(   unknowns,   ~ classify_sequence(unknown = .x, database = db) |>     filter_taxonomy() |>     print_taxonomy() ) #> [1] "Bacteria(100);\"Bacteroidetes\"(100);\"Bacteroidia\"(87);\"Bacteroidales\"(87);\"Bacteroidales\"_unclassified(87);\"Bacteroidales\"_unclassified(87)" #> [2] "Bacteria(100);\"Bacteroidetes\"(99);\"Bacteroidia\"(86);\"Bacteroidales\"(86);\"Porphyromonadaceae\"(84);\"Porphyromonadaceae\"_unclassified(84)"     #> [3] "Bacteria(100);\"Bacteroidetes\"(100);\"Bacteroidia\"(89);\"Bacteroidales\"(89);\"Porphyromonadaceae\"(84);\"Porphyromonadaceae\"_unclassified(84)"

title: phylotypr
text: ’ll notice classification three sequences varies slightly. , due use random number generator getting confidence scores bounce around 80%, results different levels filtering. get stable classification, setting random number generator seed set.seed(). get precise confidence score, set num_bootstraps = 1000 classify_seqeuence(). forewarned function take 10-times longer run 10-times number bootstraps!
code: purrr::map_chr(   unknowns,   ~ classify_sequence(unknown = .x, database = db, num_bootstraps = 1000) |>     filter_taxonomy() |>     print_taxonomy() ) #> [1] "Bacteria(100);\"Bacteroidetes\"(97.1);\"Bacteroidia\"(87.6);\"Bacteroidales\"(87.6);\"Porphyromonadaceae\"(84.7);\"Porphyromonadaceae\"_unclassified(84.7)" #> [2] "Bacteria(100);\"Bacteroidetes\"(96.9);\"Bacteroidia\"(86.1);\"Bacteroidales\"(86.1);\"Porphyromonadaceae\"(83);\"Porphyromonadaceae\"_unclassified(83)"     #> [3] "Bacteria(100);\"Bacteroidetes\"(97);\"Bacteroidia\"(84.4);\"Bacteroidales\"(84.4);\"Porphyromonadaceae\"(80.6);\"Porphyromonadaceae\"_unclassified(80.6)"

title: phylotypr
text: phylotypr package ships RDP’s v.9 training data. relatively small old (2010) relative latest versions. Also, databases available greengenes SILVA. encouraged install newer databases packages GitHub: RDP’s {trainset19} way!

title: Authors and Citation
text: Pat Schloss. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Schloss P (2024). phylotypr: Implementation Tools Classifying DNA Sequences. R package version 0.0.0.9000, http://riffomonas.org/phylotypr/, https://github.com/riffomonas/phylotypr.
code: @Manual{,   title = {phylotypr: Implementation of Tools for Classifying DNA Sequences},   author = {Pat Schloss},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000, http://riffomonas.org/phylotypr/},   url = {https://github.com/riffomonas/phylotypr}, }

title: Implementation of Tools for Classifying DNA Sequences
text: phylotypr package classification based analysis DNA sequences. package primarily implements Naive Bayesian Classifier Ribosomal Database Project. Although can classify type sequence (assuming proper database), algorithm mainly used classify 16S rRNA gene sequences.

title: Implementation of Tools for Classifying DNA Sequences
text: can install development version phylotypr GitHub : can also get official release version CRAN
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("riffomonas/phylotypr") install.packages("phylotypr")

title: Implementation of Tools for Classifying DNA Sequences
text: sure see Getting Started article see example build database classify individual multiple sequences. also need reference database classify sequences. phylotypr package ships RDP training set (v9). relatively small old (2010) relative latest versions. Also, databases available greengenes SILVA. encouraged install newer databases packages GitHub: RDP’s {trainset19} way!

title: Implementation of Tools for Classifying DNA Sequences
text: can learn underlying algorithm paper originally described algorithm published Applied Environmental Microbiology. want learn package created, sure check Riffomonas YouTube channel playlist available showing every step.

title: Build kmer database — build_kmer_database
text: Build kmer database classifying 16S rRNA gene sequences genus kmer size provided.

title: Build kmer database — build_kmer_database
code: build_kmer_database(sequences, genera, kmer_size = 8)

title: Build kmer database — build_kmer_database
text: sequences vector reference sequences genus-level taxonomic information order value genera. genera character vector genus-level taxonomic information reference sequences order value sequences. Ideally, taxonomic information provided back domain level level separated semicolons spaces. kmer_size integer indicating length nucleotide word base classification (default = 8)

title: Build kmer database — build_kmer_database
text: list object containing genus level conditional probability (conditional_prob) seeing kmer given genus well genus names (genera)

title: Build kmer database — build_kmer_database
text: Wang Q, Garrity GM, Tiedje JM, Cole JR. Naive Bayesian classifier rapid assignment rRNA sequences new bacterial taxonomy. Appl Environ Microbiol. 2007 Aug;73(16):5261-7. doi: 10.1128/AEM.00062-07. PMID: 17586664; PMCID: PMC1950982.

what: Classify 16S rRNA gene sequence fragment — classify_sequence
title: Classify 16S rRNA gene sequence fragment — classify_sequence
text: classify_seqs() function implements Wang et al. naive Bayesian classification algorithm 16S rRNA gene sequences.

title: Classify 16S rRNA gene sequence fragment — classify_sequence
code: classify_sequence(   unknown_sequence,   database,   kmer_size = 8,   num_bootstraps = 100 )

title: Classify 16S rRNA gene sequence fragment — classify_sequence
text: unknown_sequence character object representing DNA sequence needs classified database kmer database generated using build_kmer_database kmer_size integer value (default 8) indicating size kmers use classifying sequences. Higher values use RAM potentially specificity Lower values use less RAM potentially less specificity. Benchmarking found default 8 provides best specificity lowest possible memory requirement fastest execution time. num_bootstraps integer value (default 100). value num_bootstraps number randomizations perform 1/kmer_size kmers sampled (without replacement) unknown_sequence. Higher values provide greater precision confidence score.

title: Classify 16S rRNA gene sequence fragment — classify_sequence
text: list object two vectors. One vector (taxonomy) taxonomic assignment level. second vector (confidence) fraction num_bootstraps classifier gave classification level

title: Classify 16S rRNA gene sequence fragment — classify_sequence
text: Wang Q, Garrity GM, Tiedje JM, Cole JR. Naive Bayesian classifier rapid assignment rRNA sequences new bacterial taxonomy. Appl Environ Microbiol. 2007 Aug;73(16):5261-7. doi: 10.1128/AEM.00062-07. PMID: 17586664; PMCID: PMC1950982.

title: Classify 16S rRNA gene sequence fragment — classify_sequence
code: kmer_size <- 3 sequences <- c("ATGCGCTA", "ATGCGCTC", "ATGCGCTC") genera <- c("A", "B", "B")  db <- build_kmer_database(sequences, genera, kmer_size) unknown_sequence <- "ATGCGCTC"  classify_sequence(   unknown_sequence = unknown_sequence,   database = db,   kmer_size = kmer_size ) #> $taxonomy #> [1] "B" #>  #> $confidence #> [1] 1 #>

title: Filter taxonomy — filter_taxonomy
text: filter_taxonomy() function filter consensus taxonomy remove taxonomic levels confidence score min_confidence level

title: Filter taxonomy — filter_taxonomy
code: filter_taxonomy(consensus, min_confidence = 0.8)

title: Filter taxonomy — filter_taxonomy
text: consensus list object contains two slots equal sized vector. taxonomy vector contains classification taxonomic level confidence vector contains fraction bootstraps specified classification min_confidence double value 0 1 (default = 0.8). minimum fraction bootstrap replicates classification. confidence score value corresponding taxonomy removed

title: Filter taxonomy — filter_taxonomy
text: list object containing two equally sized vectors filtered remove low confidence taxonomies. One vector, taxonomy, contains taxonomy taxonomic level vector, confidence contains confidence score taxonomy. taxonomies confidence scores min_confidence

title: Filter taxonomy — filter_taxonomy
code: oscillospiraceae <- list(   taxonomy = c(     "Bacteria", "Bacillota", "Clostridia",     "Eubacteriales", "Oscillospiraceae",     "Flintibacter"   ),   confidence = c(1.00, 1.00, 0.99, 0.99, 0.98, 0.58) )  filter_taxonomy(oscillospiraceae, min_confidence = 0.80) #> $taxonomy #> [1] "Bacteria"         "Bacillota"        "Clostridia"       "Eubacteriales"    #> [5] "Oscillospiraceae" #>  #> $confidence #> [1] 1.00 1.00 0.99 0.99 0.98 #>

what: Print taxonomy for an unknown sequence — print_taxonomy
title: Print taxonomy for an unknown sequence — print_taxonomy
text: print_taxonomy() output consensus taxonomy unknown sequence confidence scores taxonomic level taxonomic level separated semi-colons

title: Print taxonomy for an unknown sequence — print_taxonomy
code: print_taxonomy(consensus, n_levels = 6)

title: Print taxonomy for an unknown sequence — print_taxonomy
text: consensus list object contains two slots equal sized vector. taxonomy vector contains classification taxonomic level confidence vector contains fraction bootstraps specified classification n_levels integer indicating number taxonomic levels expect. number observed levels less value, missing levels "_unclassified" end last named classification

title: Print taxonomy for an unknown sequence — print_taxonomy
text: character string indicating classification taxonomic level corresponding confidence parentheses. taxonomic level separated semi-colon

title: Print taxonomy for an unknown sequence — print_taxonomy
code: oscillospiraceae <- list(   taxonomy = c(     "Bacteria", "Bacillota", "Clostridia",     "Eubacteriales", "Oscillospiraceae"   ),   confidence = c(1.00, 1.00, 0.99, 0.99, 0.98) )  print_taxonomy(oscillospiraceae, n_levels = 6) #> [1] "Bacteria(100);Bacillota(100);Clostridia(99);Eubacteriales(99);Oscillospiraceae(98);Oscillospiraceae_unclassified(98)"

what: Read in a FASTA-formatted file containing DNA sequences — read_fasta
title: Read in a FASTA-formatted file containing DNA sequences — read_fasta
text: Given standard FASTA-formatted file, read_fasta read contents file create three column data frame columns sequence id, sequence , comments found header line sequence.

title: Read in a FASTA-formatted file containing DNA sequences — read_fasta
code: read_fasta(file)

title: Read in a FASTA-formatted file containing DNA sequences — read_fasta
text: file Either path file, connection, literal data (either single string raw vector) containing DNA sequences standard FASTA format. checks determine whether data DNA amino acid sequences. Files ending .gz, .bz2, .xz, .zip automatically uncompressed. Files starting ⁠http://⁠, ⁠https://⁠, ⁠ftp://⁠, ⁠ftps://⁠ automatically downloaded. Remote gz files can also autom downloaded decompressed.

title: Read in a FASTA-formatted file containing DNA sequences — read_fasta
text: data frame object three columns. id column contain non-space characters following > header line sequence; sequence column contain sequence; comment column contain text found first whitespace character header line.

title: Read in a FASTA-formatted file containing DNA sequences — read_fasta
text: seqeunces FASTA file can line breaks within read_fasta() put separate lines sequence

title: Read in a FASTA-formatted file containing DNA sequences — read_fasta
code:
temp <- tempfile() write(">seqA
ATGCATGC
>seqB
TACGTACG", file = temp) write(">seqC
TCCGATGC", file = temp, append = TRUE) write(">seqD B.ceresus UW85
TCCGATGC", file = temp, append = TRUE) write(">seq4	E. coli K12	Bacteria;Proteobacteria;
TCCGATGC", file = temp,   append = TRUE) write(">seq_4	Salmonella LT2	Bacteria;Proteobacteria;
TCCGATGC",   file = temp, append = TRUE) write(">seqE B.ceresus UW123
TCCGATGC
TCCGATGC", file = temp,   append = TRUE)  sequence_df <- read_fasta(temp)

title: Read in taxonomy files — read_taxonomy
text: Read mothur-formatted taxonomy file R data frame

title: Read in taxonomy files — read_taxonomy
code: read_taxonomy(file)

title: Read in taxonomy files — read_taxonomy
text: file Either path file, connection, literal data (either single string raw vector) containing sequence id taxonomy information sequence. Files ending .gz, .bz2, .xz, .zip automatically uncompressed. Files starting ⁠http://⁠, ⁠https://⁠, ⁠ftp://⁠, ⁠ftps://⁠ automatically downloaded. Remote gz files can also autom downloaded decompressed.

title: Read in taxonomy files — read_taxonomy
text: data frame two columns. id column contains name sequence taxonomy column, contains taxonomy sequence. string taxonomy column series taxonomic names separated semi-colons. string semi-colon end sequence

title: Read in taxonomy files — read_taxonomy
text: checks insure sequence unique id value. also assumed sequence number taxonomic levels represented second column input file.

title: Read in taxonomy files — read_taxonomy
code: temp <- tempfile() write("seqA\tA;B;C;", file = temp) write("seqB\tA;B; C;", file = temp, append = TRUE) write("seqC\tA; B;C;", file = temp, append = TRUE) write("seqD\tA;B;C", file = temp, append = TRUE) write("seqE\tA;B; C", file = temp, append = TRUE) write("seqF\tA; B;C", file = temp, append = TRUE) write("seq G\tA;B;C;", file = temp, append = TRUE)  read_taxonomy(temp) #>      id taxonomy #> 1  seqA    A;B;C #> 2  seqB    A;B;C #> 3  seqC    A;B;C #> 4  seqD    A;B;C #> 5  seqE    A;B;C #> 6  seqF    A;B;C #> 7 seq G    A;B;C

title: RDP training set v9 — trainset9_rdp
text: sequence taxonomy data 10,049 sequences found Ribosomal Database Project's trainset9_032012 training set use naive Bayesian classifier implemented {phylyotypr} R package. Originally released RDP September 2012. rdp version contains sequences provided official RDP version (9,665 bacterial 384 archaeal). pds version contains extra eukaryotic sequences including 119 chloroplasts mitochondria (10,168 total sequences). See mothur reference file page "Sources" information. sure see mothur GitHub project repositories obtain R packages containing taxonomic reference data. example v19 reference trainset19 package.

title: RDP training set v9 — trainset9_rdp
code: trainset9_rdp  trainset9_pds

title: RDP training set v9 — trainset9_rdp
text: data frame 3 columns. row represents different sequence: id Sequence accession identifier sequence DNA sequence string taxonomy Taxonomic string level separated ; object class data.frame 10169 rows 3 columns.

title: RDP training set v9 — trainset9_rdp
text: mothur-formatted files RDP sourceforge page # nolint: line_length_linter
